column1: #Text=The "War on Drugs" waged by the United States has been criticized in a report released by the Washington D.C.
#Text=-left wing based human rights group Washington Office on Latin America.

#Text=The 400-page WOLA report documents evidence that U.S. efforts to combat illegal drugs in the Americas have served to weaken democratic instutions in Latin America, and have placed the burden of the drug war upon the poorest of their citizens.

#Text=Youngers maintains that the U.S. policy of crop eradication generates social unrest, instability and violence" as poor farmers are having their source of income destroyed.

column1: #Text=Youngers further states that U.S. policies "have contributed to confusing military and law-enforcement functions, militarizing local police forces, and bringing the military into a domestic law enforcement role.

#Text=They have thus strengthened military forces at the expense of civilian authorities – in a region with a tragic history of military rule .

column1: #Text=While a senior ONDCP official has stated that the WOLA report "is filled with errors, irrelevancies, and misinterpretations" , WOLA has called for a renewed debate on drug war policies, supported by their findings and the latest government statistics that show illegal narcotics to be cheaper and more plentiful than ever before.
#Text=WOLA was founded in 1974 by Joseph Eldridge, Joyce Hill of the National Council of Churches and Thomas Quigley of the U.S.
#Text=Quigley led the Religious Task Force on El Salvador, part of a coalition called Committee In Solidarity With the People of El Salvador (CIPES).

#Text=Papers captured in El Salvador belonging to FMLN guerrilla leader, Farid Handal, "documented CIPES' connections with member groups of the Latin network and the international communist movement( Richard P.
